user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_IdleLoop:
```c
void OS_IdleLoop()
{
    /*
     * Wait until the shutdown value is set to the shutdown number
     * In most "real" embedded systems, this will never happen.
     * However it will happen in debugging situations (CTRL+C, etc).
     */
    while (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        OS_IdleLoop_Impl();
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_IdleLoop:
void OS_IdleLoop_Impl(void)
{
    /*
     * Unblock signals and wait for something to occur
     *
     * Note - "NormalSigMask" was calculated during task init to be the original signal mask
     * of the process PLUS all "RT" signals.  The RT signals are used by timers, so we want
     * to keep them masked here (this is different than the original POSIX impl).  The
     * timebase objects have a dedicated thread that will be doing "sigwait" on those.
     */
    sigsuspend(&POSIX_GlobalVars.NormalSigMask);
}
...
void UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler)
{
    /* Check if the test case registered a hook, and use the default if not */
    if (UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER) == NULL && DefaultHandler != NULL)
    {
        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);
}
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
...
void UT_SetHandlerFunction(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_HandlerFunc_t HandlerFunc, void *UserObj)
{
    UT_HookFuncPtr_t Value;

    Value.SimpleHandler = HandlerFunc;

    UT_DoSetHookFunction(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER, Value, UserObj, false);
}
...
int32 UT_DefaultStubImpl(const char *FunctionName, UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 DefaultRc, ...)
{
    int32   Retcode;
    va_list va;

    va_start(va, DefaultRc);
    Retcode = UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs(FunctionName, FuncKey, DefaultRc, va);
    va_end(va);

    return Retcode;
}
...
OS_SharedGlobalVars_t OS_SharedGlobalVars = {
    .GlobalState     = 0,
    .PrintfEnabled   = false,
    .MicroSecPerTick = 0, /* invalid, _must_ be set by implementation init */
    .TicksPerSecond  = 0, /* invalid, _must_ be set by implementation init */
    .EventHandler    = NULL,
#if defined(OSAL_CONFIG_DEBUG_PRINTF)
    .DebugLevel = 1,
#endif
}
...
#define OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER 0xABADC0DE
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No uses of <string.h> functions are present in the provided code fragments. The MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 concerns calls to standard string functions (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) that could access out of bounds. Each shown fragment does not call any of these functions or otherwise perform raw byte/character buffer operations that would require inspection under Rule 21.17:

- OS_IdleLoop(): only reads a global integer (GlobalState) and calls OS_IdleLoop_Impl(); no string operations.
- OS_IdleLoop_Impl(): calls sigsuspend() with a pointer to a sigset_t (POSIX API), not a string.h function; not subject to Rule 21.17.
- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(): calls UT_GetStubEntry(), UT_SetHandlerFunction(), and UT_DefaultStubImpl(); no string.h calls in the shown body.
- UT_GetStubEntry(): performs indexed array access and integer arithmetic; no string.h calls.
- UT_SetHandlerFunction(): assigns a function pointer and calls UT_DoSetHookFunction(); no string.h calls.
- UT_DefaultStubImpl(): uses va_list/va_start/va_end and forwards to UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs(); the shown code does not call string.h functions.
- OS_SharedGlobalVars initializer and the OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER macro: only data initialization / constant definition, no string handling.

Note: There are functions referenced but not shown (e.g., UT_DoSetHookFunction, UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs, UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs’s internals, and any other code outside the provided snippets). If those omitted functions use any of the <string.h> functions, they should be investigated for potential out-of-bounds access. Based on only the supplied code, there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 21.17, so the suspicious_frags list is empty.
